poem:
### Lunchroom Revolution

Pernil whispers  
echo through the lunchroom,  
where once wobbly trays  
seek balance  
on eager fingers.

School days—poured into  
lambent flavor,  
azure pantries awaken;  
brigaid's touch revives  
the tired noon hour.  

Plantains dance, coaxed  
by dreams of better fare—  
a melody  
of pots, pots, pots  
stirring future tables.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "He once worked at the world’s best restaurant. Now he wants to make US school food better At the Dream Mott Haven charter school this summer, more than a hundred food-service professionals lined up in the cafeteria to enjoy a school lunch prepared by the culinary team from Brigaid. Some attendees giggled like schoolchildren as they carried fire-engine-red trays filled with plates of scratch-made pernil, fried plantains and arroz con gandules through the lunchroom, taking". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
